I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The 14 Pacific developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) are fragile to varying degrees and depend heavily on trade and other international 
economic  ties  for  consumable  goods,  export  markets,  and  finance.  Except  for  the  largest 
energy- and mineral-exporters, economies in the subregion continue to perform poorly. This 
both contributes to and reflects fragility, arising from their remoteness, narrow resources bases, 
and  limited  scope  for  economies  of  scale,  as  highlighted  in  ADB  country  performance 
assessments. Strategy 2020 notes the acute challenges fragile countries face because of their 
generally  weak  policy  regimes,  small  domestic  markets,  economic  vulnerability,  and  weak 
institutions.1 It adds that ADB must align its development assistance with other funding agencies 
at the strategic and project level and pursue capacity and institutional development with more 
depth, flexibility, and longer engagement (footnote 1). This technical assistance (TA) aligns with 
the strategy in response to ongoing economic monitoring and analysis of the 14 Pacific DMCs. 
Pacific Department management and staff discussed the TA with DMC government officials and 
development partner representatives over the course several missions and meetings, though no 
mission was conducted exclusively for this purpose.2  
 
2.   An article in ADB’s Pacific Economic Monitor assessed changes in North Pacific DMCs’ 
global trade and other economic links.3 The evolution of economic links in recent decades as 
discussed in the article attracted considerable interest from DMC policy makers, who particularly 
focused on the question of how global economic developments are likely to influence the Pacific 
in coming decades and how policy can strengthen these links and help Pacific DMCs to capture 
the benefits of enhanced international ties in support of national and subregional development. 
The article highlighted the limitations of using readily available data on Pacific countries to 
analyze the development of economic links. Pacific DMC governments and key development 
partners in the subregion, such as the Asian Development Bank Institute and the Australian 
Agency for International Development, expressed interest in working with ADB to extend the 
research.  
 
3.  The TA will respond to the need for better information on these economic links to guide 
ADB and other development partner assistance, and to help shape the policies and strategies of 
Pacific  DMCs  to  reflect  and  respond  to  changing  opportunities  from,  for  example,  the 
development of the internet and the falling cost of transporting goods by sea. The TA will help 
Pacific DMCs improve their economic monitoring and policy formulation to foster countries’ 
productive engagement in an increasingly integrated global economy. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Adapting to evolving economic conditions (e.g., changing trade costs, shifts in trade 
partners’ economies, and a changing global and regional financial landscape) in an increasingly 
integrated  and  rapidly  changing  global  economy  challenges  small  and  remote  developing 
economies  in  the  Pacific.  While  Pacific  economies  are  generally  open,  posing  few  formal

barriers to trade and only moderate restrictions on investment, nontariff and institutional barriers 
to international trade and commerce persist. Constraints emerging from governments’ lack of 
capacity to efficiently facilitate and oversee trade and investment must be urgently addressed. 
Pacific  DMC  leaders  have  fully  embraced  the  goal  of  furthering  regional  cooperation  and 
integration (RCI), which reflects their collective understanding of the importance of RCI to the 
well-being of the subregion. The clearest evidence of this is provisions under ADB’s Pacific 
Approach, 2010–2014 to strengthen RCI, first endorsed by the Pacific countries in 2005.4  
 
5.  High dependence on trade and the low availability of capital make the potential benefits 
of RCI to Pacific DMCs clear, as it would enable them to achieve economies of scale by 
combining national efforts in public service provision, private sector investment, and tourism 
development. RCI could also provide important benefits by pooling risk and encouraging market 
competition that lowers prices and improves the quality and variety of goods and services 
available in the subregion. Many regional challenges such as controlling pandemics, sustainably 
managing Pacific fisheries, and adapting to rising sea levels can be effectively addressed only 
through the combined efforts of all countries in the subregion. 
 
6.  Rapidly rising engagement with new economic partners and international organizations, 
as fast-growing Asian economies engage in greater commerce and investment in the Pacific, 
requires Pacific governments to acquire new knowledge and skills for dealing with the unfamiliar 
trade and investment practices of emerging trade and investment partners in Asia, such as 
differences in accounting standards and legal procedures related to investment and financial 
transfers.  Governments  face  acute  difficulties  in  securing  and  retaining  skilled  officials  to 
oversee  new  economic  relations  because  of  their  limited  human  resource  bases  and  the 
frequent departure of skilled workers for higher-paid positions abroad. The primary goals of the 
TA are to generate more and better economic analyses of evolving trade, financial, and labor 
market  ties  through  TA-sponsored  economic  research;  build  capacity  during  collaboration 
between Pacific and international researchers under the TA; and disseminate research outputs. 
 
7.  Infrastructure development in the Pacific, including work supported by ADB, is creating 
new opportunities that require complementary actions to enhance Pacific country capacity to 
facilitate trade and investment. This includes advice and assistance in (i) creating business 
environments  to  make  countries  attractive  to  international  investors  for  their  productive 
advantages other than low wages or lax environmental controls; (ii) improving communication 
through infrastructure development and upgraded institutional capacity; (iii) enhancing countries’ 
ability to efficiently comply with international standards of customs administration, banking and 
financial  management,  and  accounting;  and  (iv)  familiarizing  countries  with  the  business 
practices and expectations of new trading and investment partners and coordinating business 
regulation. Subsequent TA is expected to focus more on building capacity in these areas guided 
by research and data generated by the TA. 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
8.  Global economic restructuring is rapidly changing economic links between Pacific DMCs 
and their traditional and emerging partners outside the subregion in terms of (i) commodity, 
merchandise, and trade services including tourism; (ii) financial and investment flows including 
development assistance; and (iii) labor migration and remittances. The TA will support applied 
research and the compilation and generation of data to better inform Pacific countries about 
                                                 
4  ADB. 2009. ADB’s Pacific Approach, 2010–2014. Manila.

3
these changes as they navigate changing economic circumstances within the subregion and 
further afield. Research will develop Pacific DMCs’ understanding of the implications of RCI and 
changing economic links and the practical steps they can take to adapt to and benefit from this 
changing environment. Research initiatives will be crafted to address the interests of Pacific 
DMC  policy  makers  with  operationally  focused  policy  advice.  The  research  will  address 
prospects for deepening and diversifying economic relationships, the implications of the Asian 
Century  on  the  economies  of  the  Pacific,  and  lessons  from  the  trade  and  investment 
experiences  of  other  small  island  economies.5 Capacity  will  be  built  through  collaboration 
between  international  and  national  economists  in  conducting  the  research  and  later  by 
supporting  countries’  implementation  of  the  policy  recommendations  arising  from  research 
within the framework of enhanced RCI road maps.  
 
9.  The TA will advise and assist Pacific DMCs on policies needed to adjust to closer 
regional and international integration and on how to respond to the challenges and opportunities 
the integration brings. Improved RCI road maps for individual Pacific DMCs and associated 
plans  for  capacity  building  to  assist  Pacific  country  engagement  with  emerging  economic 
partners in trade, finance, and labor market cooperation and/or integration will be supported 
under  the  TA.  Pacific  DMCs’  communication  with  bilateral  and  multilateral  organizations 
engaged in trade and investment facilitation will be improved through training and experience 
sharing between Pacific countries, and between the Pacific and other subregions that have 
made greater progress in RCI with ADB assistance. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA will enhance RCI within and beyond the Pacific by improving understanding of 
how the Pacific’s economic linkages have evolved and what the most serious barriers to greater 
integration have been. Improving the availability of indicators for tracking progress in economic 
integration will support future RCI efforts. The impact of the TA will be measured by the annual 
compilation of integration indicators and by research reports and evidence of the uptake of 
research results in the Pacific. 
 
11.  The outcome will be improved availability of indicators and knowledge products on the 
economic linkages in Pacific DMCs and the opportunities and barriers to greater RCI in the 
region. The TA will help strengthen Pacific DMCs’ ability to plan and manage their economies in 
the face of changing international economic environment and improve Pacific stakeholders’ 
understanding of ongoing economic transformations and future developments in links joining the 
Pacific, Asia, and the broader global economy. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  The TA will conduct focused research that will produce reports examining the experience 
and structural potential of selected Pacific countries to engage and integrate in key areas of 
economic activity: (i) imports to Pacific DMCs, (ii) exports from Pacific DMCs, (iii) trade in 
tourism and other services, (iv) investment and financial flows, (v) development assistance 
flows, and (vi) labor migration and remittances. By compiling and analyzing available indicators 
of country activity in these areas, and by working to enhance indicator availability in the future, 
research under the TA will provide to Pacific countries and development organizations working 
with them a more nuanced understanding of these economic relationships and their evolution 
over recent decades. The research will examine the trends, drivers, opportunities, and factors 
                                                 
5  H.S. Kohli et al. 2011. Asia 2050: Realizing the Asian Century. New Delhi: Sage Publications / ADB.

4  
that  inhibit  greater  Pacific  DMC  integration.  Improved  understanding  will  facilitate  the 
formulation of improved national development policies and strategies to respond to and take 
advantage of the changing global economic landscape. 
 
13.  How to characterize changes in the strength of economic ties between countries is well 
established. The toolkit of analytical approaches well suited to this research includes basic 
descriptive statistical analysis of compiled indicators related to the defined areas of linkage, the 
calculation of trade intensity and revealed comparative advantage indicators, and econometric 
examination of drivers of evolving economic linkage, such as the gravity model estimation 
framework. The main research challenges relate to the timeliness and coverage of available 
indicators and to sustaining government counterpart interest and engagement in the planned 
research and the dissemination of research results. To address the risk that existing data will be 
inadequate to enable tracking past and future progress in economic integration and its drivers 
and  consequences,  the  TA  will  develop  new  indicators  and  detailed  plans  to  enhance 
integration indicators available to Pacific DMCs in the coming years. 
 
14.   Because of the large number of Pacific DMCs and distinct areas of economic linkage 
that will be examined under this TA, it would be unwise to attempt to cover all DMCs and topics 
in the initial phase of what is expected to be a long-term stream of research. Accordingly, the TA 
will focus on a few country and linkage-area pairings with particular relevance or high availability 
of data. The table summarizes an initial set of planned studies that will be discussed and 
finalized during the planned project inception workshop.

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund.6  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The TA will be implemented from September 2013 to August 2015. ADB will be the 
executing and implementing agency. Ministries responsible for trade, investment, and labor 
                                                 
6  Established by ADB.

5
policy in participating Pacific DMCs will conduct TA research in partnership with ADB. TA 
activities will be coordinated with a number of other ongoing7 or planned TA projects.   
 
17.  A team will be recruited for 37 person-months of consulting inputs on an intermittent 
basis. The team will have a project coordinator (national, up to 16 person-months) and at least 
six research economists (international, total of 21 person-months inputs, recruited on output-
based,  lump-sum  contracts)  with  expertise  in  foreign  direct  investment  and  international 
financial transfers, labor markets and migration, and trade (divided across import trade, export 
trade, and trade in services with a focus on international tourism). Deliverables will include 
quarterly progress reports to be prepared by the project coordinator and six research reports 
developed from a detailed outline including a literature review, an initial draft, and a final draft—
each with associated briefs outlining key policy issues identified in the main report. ADB will 
engage the consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
18.  Established ADB project monitoring and evaluation indicators will be applied to assess 
the effectiveness of the TA, as broadly outlined in the design and monitoring framework. TA 
inception will refine the initial monitoring milestones presented in this report and provide the 
bases upon which TA performance can be judged. The indicators will expand on the general 
indicators suggested in the design and monitoring framework. During TA implementation, ADB 
will convene semiannual reviews of TA implementation and effectiveness and seek external 
stakeholders’ views on TA outputs. To facilitate this review, quarterly updates on TA progress 
and issues arising in implementation will be prepared by the project coordinator and submitted 
to ADB. Regional workshops convened as part of the TA will monitor progress achieved and 
guide future areas of focus. TA reports will be shared with development partners supporting 
related initiatives. These partners will be invited to participate in planned TA review meetings 
and collaborate with ADB-supported researchers to extend research outputs. 
 
19.  Research findings and other outputs such as plans for enhancing the availability of 
economic  linkage  indicators  will  be  disseminated  through  TA  reports  to  be  shared  with 
stakeholders through regional workshops, country seminars, and publications including in the 
Pacific Economic Monitor (footnote 3). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
Evolving Linkages of the Pacific Economies, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A team of individual consultants will be recruited for up to 37 person-months (21 months 
international and 16 months national) by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in accordance with 
ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) to implement 
the 2-year technical assistance (TA).  
 
2.  The consultant team will be guided by the ADB Pacific Department Economics Team in 
coordination  with  Pacific  government  representatives  charged  with  formulating  national 
development and regional integration plans. The project coordinator will manage the day-to-day 
activities of the research team, working with ADB economists to communicate with research 
economists regarding the six research papers and to organize project research activities and 
workshops. Six research economists with expertise and experience in the areas of economic 
activity that will be the focus of the research will be contracted to prepare detailed analyses of 
evolving economic links in the selected areas. These analyses will include, where appropriate, 
reference to and study of the experience of the efforts of other archipelagic regions such as the 
Caribbean and of individual small island nations to advance regional cooperation and integration 
(RCI)  to  address  economic  problems  in  the  six  areas  of  economic  activity.  An  inception 
workshop will take stock of existing research and discuss detailed plans for the research to be 
conducted under the TA. To kick off the dissemination of the six complete research studies, a 
concluding  workshop  will  present  and  discuss  research  findings  and  recommendations  for 
enhancing the availability of economic integration indicators for Pacific countries, as well as plan 
final publications. 
 
A.  Project Coordinator (national, up to 16 person-months, full time) 
 
3.  Responsible for TA implementation, the project coordinator will have a postgraduate 
degree in economics or a related field and at least 5 years of research and/or work experience 
on RCI initiatives. A strong background in RCI initiatives in Asia and the Pacific is essential, 
preferably gained working with relevant national or regional organizations, and exposure to RCI 
initiatives in other regions is preferred. Fluency in English is essential.   
 
4.  The project coordinator will: 
(i)  coordinate the TA under the guidance of ADB, including communication with the 
project  team,  organizing  meetings  and  workshops,  assisting  with  the 
administrative tasks associated with TA implementation, and leading information 
sharing and dialogue with country and development partner stakeholders in line 
ministries  and  with  focal  points  representing  relevant  regional  organizations 
active in the Pacific in pursuit of RCI; 
(ii)  help identify and engage partner institutions and individuals to carry out research 
and participate in knowledge-sharing seminars and workshops; 
(iii)  lead the preparation of progress reports on the research conducted under the 
TA; 
(iv)  coordinate and manage the inputs, activities, and outputs of TA researchers; 
(v)  manage the delivery of TA results in accordance with the design and monitoring 
framework, including monitoring and managing TA risks, initiating and leading 
discussions of key implementation issues with governments, and managing TA 
quality control and assurance;  
(vi)  organize  workshops  to  share  research  findings  with  ADB  staff,  government 
officials and representatives, and other stakeholders;  
(vii)  identify  counterpart  staff  to  be  members  of  the  TA  team  and  coordinate  all

(viii)  assist in administering all contracts under the TA, including providing assistance

(ix)  ensure  that  development  partners  are  informed  of  research  and  activities 
undertaken by the TA and that related efforts are coordinated through periodic

(x)  collect  information  regarding  related  TA  and  research  conducted  by  other

(xi)  undertake other tasks as required by ADB and as may be required for successful 
TA implementation. 
 
B.  Economists with research expertise in development assistance, international 
capital flows, labor markets and migration, and trade (merchandise imports, 
merchandise exports, and trade in services) (6 positions, international, 3.5 person-
months each, intermittent) 
 
5.  The research economists will report to the project team and project coordinator. Each 
will have a postgraduate degree in economics, policy analysis, or a closely related field, as well 
as  at  least  5  years  of  experience  in  a  relevant  field.  A  record  of  research  outputs  that 
demonstrates familiarity with the data and existing literature in the areas of economic linkage 
that form the focus of the research is essential. A strong background in the economies of the 
Pacific and existing contacts in participating Pacific countries is highly desirable. Fluency in 
English is essential.  
 
6.  The research economists will: 
(i)  develop a detailed research plan, including proposed analytical methods and 
detailed descriptions of data to be analyzed, and an outline for the research 
report in her or his designated study area: development assistance, export trade, 
import trade, labor finance and investment, migration and remittances, or service 
trade (tourism);  
(ii)  review  the  literature  on  the  selected  research  area,  covering  the  history  of 
economic  exchanges  in  the  focus  area,  economic  theories  regarding  the 
determinants of the strength of linkage, and forecasts about future developments 
in the linkages; 
(iii)  construct a database that includes available data, characterizing and measuring 
the  extent  of  linkage  between  selected  countries  in  the  Pacific  and  other 
economies in the designated area of economic association;
